review.title: EmojiNet: Building a Machine Readable Sense Inventory for Emoji
review.abstract: Emoji are a contemporary and extremely popular way to enhance electronic communication. Without rigid semantics attached to them, emoji symbols take on different meanings based on the context of a message. Thus, like the word sense disambiguation task in natural language processing, machines also need to disambiguate the meaning or sense of an emoji. In a first step toward achieving this goal, this paper presents EmojiNet, the first machine readable sense inventory for emoji. EmojiNet is a resource enabling systems to link emoji with their context-specific meaning. It is automatically constructed by integrating multiple emoji resources with BabelNet, which is the most comprehensive multilingual sense inventory available to date. The paper discusses its construction, evaluates the automatic resource creation process, and presents a use case where EmojiNet disambiguates emoji usage in tweets. sections.heading: 3.4 EmojiNet Web Application
sections.text: We are introducing EmojiNet as a web application at http: / / emojinet.knoesis.org /. The current version of EmojiNet supports searching for emojis based on Unicode characters and short code names. In addition, the user can search emojis by specifying part of the tagged meaning and returns a list of emojis marked with the meaning searched for. Table 2 lists statistics for EmojiNet. It currently contains a total of 1,074 emojis. It has a total of 3,206 valid meaning definitions shared among 875 emojis, with an average of 4 senses per emoji. The resource is freely available to the public for research purposes 13.

sections.heading: 4 Evaluation
sections.text: Specifically, we evaluate the closest neighborhood-based image processing algorithm we have used to integrate emoji resources and the most common sense-based and popular sense-based word-disambiguation algorithms that we use to assign meanings to emoji sense labels. Note that we do not evaluate EmojiNet's usability based on a selected task or benchmark dataset. While sense inventories such as BabelNet have been evaluated based on benchmark WSD datasets or word-similarity calculations, emoji sense disambiguization and finding emoji similarities are two separate research issues that have not yet been explored [8]. The focus of this work is not on investigating or solving these issues.

sections.text: Next, we evaluate how well the closest image processing algorithm matches each image in it with the images in Ix. Ix could contain multiple images for a particular emoji (7 images per emoji on average), based on different rendering platforms on which the emoji could appear. sections.heading: 4.3 EmojiNet at Work
sections.text: The tweets we are looking at are: T1: Pray for my family, God has won an angel today. T2: Difficult to win, but we have it man Lets celebrate! EmojiNet lists high five (noun) and prays (verb) as valid senses for the above emoji. For high five (noun), EmojiNet lists three definitions, and for prayer (verb) it lists two definitions. We include all words that appear in their respective definitions as possible contextual words that can occur when the appropriate sense is used in a sentence (tweet in this case). For each sense, EmojiNet extracts the following sentences of words: Prayer, Thanksgiving, Saints, Higher Gods that we have exaggerated.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion and Future Work
sections.text: This paper outlined the construction of EmojiNet, the first machine-readable sensory inventory to understand the meaning of emoji. It integrates four different emoji resources from the web to extract emoji senses and align those senses with BabelNet. We evaluated the automatic creation of EmojiNet by evaluating (i) the closest neighborhood-based image processing algorithm used to align various emoji senses from the web with BabelNet. We plan to expand our work in the future by expanding the meaning definitions extracted from BabelNet to include words extracted from tweets that are most common and popular meaning-based word disambiguation algorithms used to align various emoji senses extracted from the web. We also plan to expand our work in the future by adding words extracted from BabelNet to include words extracted from tweets, using a word-embedding model trained on tweets that contain emoji. We also plan to evaluate the usefulness of EmojiNet by first evaluating emoji-based, and then evaluating emoji-based emotions from emoji-net.
